comments.body: Does this only work on `com.android.library` projects or will it also work on other library plugins like `com.android.dynamic-feature`?
The primary use case is `com.android.library` for module and plugins. What is the use case for `com.android.dynamic-feature`?

It's a variant of an Android library/module that can be distributed dynamically by Google Play when your app needs it.

It's likely that if people are using Flutter modules for embedding in existing apps that will want to use dynamic features at some point.
I see. cc @xster
Seems sensible. Could you open a github issue with an intend scenario and we could try it once the minimal path is a bit more settled?
Are we sure we want to remove this?  I believe that's set by default for plugins, but what if a plugin author explicitly wanted this?

Talked offline and it sounds like this is the right way to go - but maybe you can expand the comment here explaining why we're convinced this works beyond just that our templates happen to include it today in our templates.
Solved offline :)

Are we sure these are the only libraries that plugins will be depending on?

For instance, what if plugins instruct users today to add dependencies to their own build.gradle, and now that breaks.
Solved offline!

I'm not sure this one got resolved.  What are we going to do/print if we fail to build a plugin because it is missing dependencies, but it used to build because the application listed those dependencies?
This is under a flag now, so we will see.

Not for this PR, but it would probably be nice to have a version of flutter.jar that is interface only.  The engine already produces an intermediary for that and then adds in libflutter.so.  We could probably make a step where we also just produce a flutter.jar that just has the Java classes and no libflutter.so, so we don't end up in this strange scenario where we're picking a specific build variant that isn't necessarily what the final build will use.
I like that idea. üëç
Top level comment for what this file is for (vs flutter.gradle etc)
It's hard to figure out what flutter command and which part of the process this script maps to and is it supposed to have side effects / affect files/changes that should be source controlled etc.
Added the comment and copyrights. :)
How does this work exactly? Is this going through all the classes in the dex and looking for whether a FlutterPlugin class exists? Wouldn't it be true even if they don't instantiate one?
Added a comment. This is just checking to see if the project uses/applies the Flutter plugin. Plugins are just a class.
What happens if this script is ran against an app that uses the support libraries and hasn't migrated to AndroidX/isn't using Jetifier?

this won't affect the output artifact "AAR" since it's a `compileOnly` dependency.  My understanding is that annotations are just hints, and any reference in code is removed and it's not included in either the output `.jar` or `.aar`.
